fields.description: Apthorp Penthouse Architecture and Design Services

content.value: Before joining General Assembly, Colin studied product design and received his Masters in Interior Architecture from the Rhode Island School of Design, where he focused on the re-use of existing structures. Since then, he continues to explore the relationships between object, person and place. This interest in the human scale can be seen through his use and understanding of material, detail and texture. Colin has been with General Assembly since 2014 and became a partner in 2019.

Sarah has been living and designing in New York City for the past two decades. After working at several international architecture firms, her attraction to the intimacy and scale of residential design led her to start General Assembly in 2011.Since then, Sarah has looked towards each new project as a unique opportunity to further develop an understanding of how color, light, and texture can make places feel personal. Sarah received a Masters degree in Architecture from UCLA, and a Bachelor of Arts from New York University.

General Assembly is a boutique, full-service design office that refers to the joining of people, objects and materials that go into a successful project. The studio creates homes rooted in the spaces and narratives of its clients.

Helmed by Sarah Zames and Colin Stief, who bring together their backgrounds in architecture, furniture and interiors, the studio has a distinct approach that looks at the needs of a project at every scale, from finishes and detailing to the way we move through space. General Assembly creates bespoke solutions that can range from custom furniture and millwork to spatial layout. Their sophisticated interiors champion craft, foreground honest materials, and heirloom-quality objects meant to improve with time and enhance everyday life.
Founded in 2011, General Assembly has completed a diverse roster of highly-acclaimed projects from New York City to Upstate New York, the Hamptons and London.

In 2021, General Assembly opened Assembly Line, a brick and mortar storefront with a curated selection of home renovation materials, furniture and lighting from a global roster of independent brands and designers.

In 2021, In celebration of General Assembly’s 10-year anniversary, the studio opened its first brick and mortar store with an eye for home improvement, high quality materials, and thoughtful yet simplified interior design. Located in Brooklyn’s Boerum Hill neighborhood, Assembly Line is a space for collaboration, community, and a shared love for beautiful materials, products, and spaces with a hand-picked selection of some of our favorite furniture, lighting and renovation items.

fields.title: Sarah Zames and Colin Stief
fields.description: Sarah Zames and Colin Stief founders of General Assembly in their shop Assembly Line in Brooklyn

content.value: General Assembly has overseen the full interior renovation and reconfiguration of a 1960s cedar shingled beach bungalow for a Manhattan-based creative couple. The studio has created a relaxed, year-round getaway outside the low key hamlet of Amagansett that calls to mind the Hamptons of decades past.

For inspiration, the studio drew on the many nearby humble, historic shingled homes and the site's location near the water in Napeague State Park. The studio drew from the rugged Modernism of California’s Sea Ranch, and Norman Jaffe adding softened finishes and details like solid wood millwork, patterned wallpapers and handmade tile that echo the color palette of the surrounding shrubs and trees.

The project showcases General Assembly’s creative approach to space adding an additional bathroom and expanded kitchen within the home’s limited existing footprint. A series of simple and considered design details and material choices give the home a highly crafted, functional and tactile quality, from the striking pine green tile flooring in the kitchen and dining room to the custom stainless steel soaking tub in the primary bath and graphic wood railing cuts out that cast beautiful shadows throughout the day.

General Assembly has created a unique interiors concept for one of the residences at 144 Vanderbilt. Housed in the new Fort Greene building developed by Tankhouse with architecture by SO-IL, the space is at once a model apartment, an immersive domestic environment and shoppable design gallery.

The design of the beautifully appointed, light-filled 2,000 sq-ft duplex apartment compliments the building’s high level of craftsmanship, exposed concrete ceilings and natural oak floors, while showcasing General Assembly’s approach to sophisticated, material-driven interiors.

Its series of distinct yet interconnected spaces -  a kitchen / dining area, living room, den, office, primary and kids bedrooms - play with tonality, each grounded by an earthy color palette from General Assembly’s recently-launched collection of limewash paints for Ressource and Armadillo rugs. The apartment has been arranged with a curated selection of newly-released, handcrafted and made-to-order furniture, lighting, art and accessories from the studio's storefront, Assembly Line.

The result is a space that embodies General Assembly's design ethos, championing craft, foregrounding honest materials, and heirloom-quality objects meant to improve with time and enhance everyday life.

For the Key West, Florida, vacation home of their longtime client, a New York-based family of four, General Assembly has embraced the sense of vibrancy, playfulness and eclectic style characteristic of its coastal setting. The studio’s interiors for the modern 1970s home set the tone for a relaxed getaway that is very much rooted in its place.

Throughout the home, the clean lines and geometric volumes of the architecture are balanced by warmer elements and a striking mix of patterned tile, textiles and wallpaper. General Assembly looked to the interiors of the iconic Ernest Hemingway House in the Old Town of Key West, 1980s Florida design and advertisements for inspiration, even taking cues from the vintage wood paneled Chrysler LeBaron the owners purchased for the home.

The island’s mix of contemporary and historic architectural styles, particularly its earliest houses handcrafted by ship makers in the early 1800s, informed the mix of simple, utilitarian detailing and natural materials. Spindle backed lounge chairs in the living room are upholstered in colorful floral fabric and streamlined rounded pulls in the kitchen have been painted lime green.

A sense of comfort and ease permeates every space, especially evident in the open flow from the kitchen to the dining room and living room spaces. Designed around a custom bar, the living room is outfitted with a natural jute rug and oversized slipcovered sofas. Large sliding doors and skylights connect the space to the outdoors and the pool area beyond.

General Assembly has reimagined the interiors and layout for the home of a young family on Manhattan’s Upper West Side. A redesign of two previously combined apartments, the space pays tribute to the grandeur and elegance of a historic pre-war building while creating a home that feels both contemporary and timeless.

Designed by Gaetano Ajello, who shaped much of the neighborhood’s architecture in the early 20th century, the classic pre-war features like grand, ornate facades with intricate architectural details, decorative moldings, cornices and stone carvings, are referenced in the studio’s material choices and balanced by the clean lines and warm tones of the apartment’s ample custom millwork.

The new floor plan retains the distinct living zones that are characteristic of pre-war apartments, while being updated to better suit the clients’ lifestyle, maximize natural light and city views. Larger, more open living spaces, ideal for hosting and entertaining, have been created along with private, intimate bedrooms and dedicated guest areas.

The apartment’s carefully selected finishes have been thoughtfully juxtaposed to emphasize their natural beauty. Nowhere is this more evident than the generous kitchen, which retains a sense of intimacy even as it opens up to the living room beyond through a series of elegant pocket doors. The combination of stone counters, a solid marble island and a built in white oak table lends an immersive and inviting atmosphere to one of the most utilized spaces in the home. For the living room, General Assembly paired two organic, custom-designed coffee tables in solid white oak and travertine in the open plan space.

Elsewhere, built-ins have been integrated to maximize storage, another nod to the original detailing of the apartment. Beside the dining table General Assembly has placed a bar with high gloss finishes including unlacquered brass cabinets, a marble countertop and a smoked glass mirror. In the hallway, thick shelves have been carved into the plaster wall, including hidden drawers and storage below.

The private spaces function as a retreat for each member of the family. The primary suite has a dedicated wallpapered entry, and deep colored lime wash and plush materials like the custom olive green headboard and alpaca rug.  The primary bath was designed with dramatic stone that feels like a retreat while the kids’ rooms each have their own color palette and personality.

A Cubist painting sets the palette for this cozy and inviting one bedroom apartment in Manhattan's West Village. The space is part of a perpetually-preserved history, with both the building and the apartment having been woven and re-woven into the urban fabric of this historic neighborhood time and time again with each passing generation of homeowners. With an amalgamation of rich and characterful materials from lush velvets and patinated brass to painterly patterns, this 1, 200 square foot home is brimming with warmth and nostalgia. Crisp detailing and thoughtful millwork strike a comforting balance alongside a mixture of dark wood, artful tiling, and lived-in textures reminiscent of a university social club. Found throughout, a curated selection of family heirlooms, keepsakes and collectables – from Murano glass fixtures and well-worn rugs to a drawing by Andy Warhol – offer a storied feeling of familiar, yet intriguing history.

A significant part of General Assembly’s scope of work was the considered combining of the two apartments that made up its pre-existing space (a small one bedroom apartment and a studio). It was important that through this next iteration of the overall space, a thread of connectivity remained present between both apartments. With this in mind, the apartment features millwork thresholds that highlight the passing from one apartment to the other. The formal layout is intentionally compartmentalized with multiple small rooms, each with their own distinct aesthetic traits by way of rich color and comforting materiality. Though each room in the apartment offers immense personality, an undeniable sense of substance and depth ties each space to the other.

Housed in a historic building on Manhattan's Upper West Side, the apartment - originally made up of former staff's quarters - was purchased as one narrow, empty space.  When the building opened in 1907 elevators were fairly new and people were accustomed to the traditional townhouse layout putting the staff and laundry rooms on the top floor, not yet realizing it was prime real estate.

The apartment was originally a series of three small units, laid out in a long narrow line. General Assembly chose to embrace the length of the space and designed a long corridor with windows to the courtyard on one side and doors to each bedroom on the other. Nods to the historic building were included in the interior design, arched doorways and custom arched window shutters reference the existing arched windows of the building. In addition, exaggerated plaster moldings and plaster details throughout reflect the beautiful plaster details in the building's common areas. While some historic details lived on, the taste of the  homeowner are reflected in the choice natural materials like European oak, handmade tile, and local Vermont marble. In balancing the more formal design choices, the studio incorporated minimal detailing to the baseboards and custom millwork.

In the end, this project was one of General Assembly's most successful yet, through it’s melding of the existing space with a history and story to tell, and trusting clients who provided a freedom to create and not just duplicate.

content.value: A young family tasked GA with the renovation of a townhouse in the center of the historic Brooklyn neighborhood, Boerum Hill. Our interventions live within the existing footprint and add another layer to  building’s rich history, maintaining the original layout, flooring and plaster and stone detailing.  The interior scope of work was inspired  by the abstract expressionist art movement and included new finishes and lighting throughout, custom millwork and furniture specification.

content.value: The renovation and rehabilitation of this 19th century stone house is located on the Pennsylvania-New York border, right outside the town of Callicoon. The homeowners had been vacationing in the area for years before finding and falling in love with the 4.5 acre property.

The original Stone House was built in 1780 and was updated with a second structure in 1877. The addition and multiple renovations left the house with layers of finishes and a memory of how the home accommodated people's needs through time. Our sensitive approach recognized that we are one piece in the building's long life. While there was a drastic reorganization of the interior spaces, we took care to respect the building's thick stone structure. All windows were updated in their existing openings and two existing window openings were repurposed to become doors to the exterior, framing the homeowners' favorite views of the property.

The interior was reorganized to maximize usable space within the existing envelope. The stairway was relocated to optimize head height on the second floor and create the large open living space on the ground floor while the original stone structure was turned into the master suite. Throughout the home, our work contrasts with the existing structure. The new elements sit within the stone shell and there is a clear line between what was already there and what we added. The original exposed stone, plaster and beams contrast with the new clean walls and lighting, the remnants of the cut joists in the new stair opening add to the palimpsest.

Throughout its life, the stone house has reflected people's ideas of comfort and what a home is. While our renovation modernized the home to meet today's standards, our rehabilitation gives this historic house the ability to continue to adapt to the current and future owners needs.

content.value: This 3,400 square foot home in Southampton received an extensive interior renovation to create a family refuge. Catering to the two generations living in the home, the space is a juxtaposition of the informality of a traditional country house with the formality that such a grand space required. In order to create something entirely unique, the house is filled with our modern interpretation of classic detailing. GA handled all aspects of the process from layout reconfiguration to interior design, including finishes fixtures and several custom designed furniture pieces.

content.value: The river town of Hudson has become an escape for New York creatives looking for a little more space and a slower pace of life. The homeowners, who split their time between New York, Los Angeles, and London, came to General Assembly to brighten up and modernize their new country home located just outside the town.

The original floor plan was made up of multiple small rooms, leading to a dark interior and a disorienting circulation.  In order to address these issues,  non-essential interior walls were removed, added windows, and opened up an exterior wall with folding glass doors.  The result is a more open and communal living space.  The natural and neutral finishes throughout emphasize the heavy timber construction, which General Assembly took great care to not disrupt with the necessary modernization of the second floor.  In the home office, primary suite and guest room, color and vintage furnishings create spaces that break the neutral palette and  mood.  The guest room’s floral wallpaper for example, was salvaged to keep a little of the home’s history and the clients leaned into the patterns with their decoration and styling.

The result of the renovation is a home that has been modernized to meet the needs of the family who live there, without losing the character that attracted them to the property. We are excited to see the house grow as the young family continues to add to it’s history.

content.value: Located on one of our favorite blocks in the West Village and originally built in 1900, this quintessential loft building gives a feeling of the old New York. The renovation, which slowly took place over multiple years, evolved with the family. In order to accommodate the changing needs of everyone in the home, various projects were completed, including the addition of a bedroom, a full kitchen renovation and updates to lighting, finishes and furniture throughout. Overall, we worked to keep the open feeling of the loft and add to the warmth of the existing space. The different phases of the project allowed us to be very considerate with our interventions, adding or subtracting from the home without sacrificing its unique character. With its ample proportions, high ceilings, and design details that blur the lines between old and new, the completed space recalls the comfort and serenity of an old country house, right in the heart of Manhattan.

content.value: A short drive from Manhattan, General Assembly transformed an existing barn set across from a modern glass house into a comfortable guest space and studio. In 1967, the original owners of the property commissioned the glass house to be built and converted an existing barn into a private studio space. To suit the owners frequently visiting friends and family, the existing interior was reconfigured to include a bedroom, kitchen and dining space on the first floor and a flexible second floor including an open home office, living space and a small bunk room. In contrast to the open main house, the neighboring building is meant to feel solid while remaining connected to the exterior.  On the ground level, slate flooring extends to meet the site's natural rock formations and two sets of large windows provide directed views while the tiled surfaces and furniture relate to the the mid century aesthetic.

projectPage.title: Shelter Island
credits: Photography: Joe Fletcher Landscape Design: Buttercup Design
featuredIn: T: The New York Times Style

content.value: The pool house was designed as a retreat and relaxation space for a busy mother and daughter duo. The footprint of the building is minimal - large enough to entertain some guests, but small enough to remain intimate when just two or three people are using the space.  Divided into three areas, ranging in size and exposure to the outdoors, the building houses a living room, dining space and yoga / meditation room.

The design of the space is based on a series of contrasts. Enclosed and open spaces. Dark and light. Private and public. With such a with a simple concept, it was important to keep the materials in tune with the surrounding landscape. The shou sugi ban charred cypress provides a contrast between the light interior, and the texture of the material played beautifully with the varying natural light throughout the seasons in the area. We look forward to watching this building age into the surrounding landscape and provide a space of escape for years to come.

content.value: General Assembly reimagined an existing stone house and barn on a farm in New York's Catskill Mountains. To preserve the spirit of both spaces, existing elements were re-used and repurposed where possible with the addition of warm materials including reclaimed wood and living metal finishes throughout.  Even though both spaces were approached with a gentle touch, significant layout changes were necessary to make them suitable for modern living and serve as counterparts to each other. The stone house serves as the family's main home and is inherently solid with a traditional compartmentalized interior layout, while the open barn is open and connected to the exterior through a large sliding glass door.

content.value: For a creative couple with busy travel schedules, General Assembly created an airy, welcoming home for them to come back to at the end of each trip. Taking advantage of the home's large windows, the space is infused with sunlight and inspired the use of textured, natural materials throughout; from white oak millwork in the kitchen to concrete in the bathroom. General Assembly created balance with darker accents such as steel detailing and a large custom concrete fireplace.

The space is just under 800sf so almost everything was built to suit, with an eye toward maximizing efficiency - such as a deceptively deep built-in dresser in the master bedroom, and a secret cat corridor that links the upper bookshelves from room to room.

content.value: After trying and failing to find an apartment with character, the owners of this space opted to combine two new development apartments in Brooklyn's Vinegar Hill neighborhood. To add warmth to the sterile spaces, General Assembly incorporated natural materials where possible, including concrete walls and ceilings, reclaimed wood floors, marble, and custom walnut millwork throughout. Steel and glass doors divide public and private areas, and full height flush millwork doors stretch the space upward, making the most of the apartments ceiling heights. What this apartment demonstrates best, is that the combination of modern clean detailing with natural materials can result in both a comfortable and crisp environment.
